PostValue.explanation: For the EA/rationalist community this piece is fairly important: farmed animal suffering is a large, tractable cause area and 80,000 Hours' problem profile can meaningfully influence career choices and resource allocation. It is not foundational to core EA priorities like AI safety or biosecurity, but it is load-bearing for people deciding between cause areas and for movement-building in animal advocacy. For general humanity the post is moderately important: the underlying issue affects billions of animals and has environmental and public‑health co‑benefits, but an informational profile aimed at career guidance has limited direct impact on policy or mass behavior compared with systemic interventions. Uncertainties about strategy and long‑term effects limit how decisive the profile is.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback: 1) Add concrete numbers and sources for the scale claims and for the efficacy of interventions. The post repeatedly asserts “billions” and “room for optimism” without giving citations or units of measurement (animals slaughtered, average lifetime suffering, species weights). Include reputable datasets (FAO, peer-reviewed estimates for farmed animals and wild-capture fisheries), a clear metric for impact (e.g., suffering-weighted animal-years or animal-counts with a note on moral weighting), and at least one sensitivity analysis showing how conclusions change under different plausible parameter values. 2) Explicitly address major strategic counterarguments and failure modes. The current text omits plausible backfire and trade-off scenarios (rebound effects from cheaper meat, industry resistance and regulatory capture, substitution into other forms of animal use, and links to wild-animal suffering or longtermist priorities). Add a short robustness section that lays out the top 3 counterarguments, evidence for/against each, and how recommended interventions would mitigate those risks. 3) Prioritize interventions instead of listing many options at equal weight. Use a simple framework (importance, tractability, neglectedness) and apply it to the main levers (corporate campaigns, policy, alternative proteins, legal work, research, movement building). Give 2–4 high-priority career/organizational pathways with concise justification and an estimate of relative cost-effectiveness or timescale, or clearly explain why more research is needed before ranking. This will make the profile more actionable for readers deciding where to focus time or donations.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Strong, actionable feedback that targets the post’s main weaknesses: lack of sourcing/numbers (which undermines credibility), omission of major counterarguments/failure modes (which invites valid pushback), and failure to prioritize interventions (which reduces actionability). Implementing these would materially improve the profile and avoid embarrassing gaps for an EA audience. Some suggestions (e.g., full sensitivity analyses) are work-intensive and could lengthen the piece, but are valuable if done succinctly or linked to appendices.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: "EA Handbook" appears to be a collective/resource title or pseudonymous/organizational author (a guide for newcomers) rather than a single prominent individual. It is reasonably known within EA/rationalist circles as a reference but not a well‑known author or frequent public figure; it has virtually no recognition outside the EA community.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is clear, well-structured and easy to follow: simple language and numbered key points summarize the issue, scope, uncertainties, and avenues for action. It is appropriately concise for a summary. Its weaknesses are that it is high-level and generic—no concrete data, examples, or evidentiary support are provided—so the argument is more of a summary/assertion than a compelling, fully substantiated case.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is mostly a summary of well-known points: the large scale of factory farming harms, existing advocacy/alternative-protein work, and policy/research pathways. For EA readers the content is familiar (80,000 Hours framing and career-focus are standard), so it’s not novel. For the general public it’s slightly more informative (career-impact framing and emphasis on long‑term uncertainties are less commonly foregrounded), but the core claims are widely reported and not original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The profile is logically organized, clearly links the problem (vast numbers of confined animals) to plausible intervention routes (policy, corporate outreach, alternative proteins, research, movement-building), and explicitly acknowledges key uncertainties. Its claims about scale and welfare harms rest on well-established facts about industrial animal agriculture and production volumes, and the piece lays out sensible considerations for career impact and tractability. Weaknesses: The strongest empirical evidence is limited to scale and general welfare science; evidence for the effectiveness and cost‑effectiveness of many advocated interventions (e.g., corporate campaigns, long‑term effects of alternative‑protein R&D, large-scale behaviour change) is sparser, more mixed, and often conditional on optimistic assumptions. The profile relies on forecasts and strategic judgements that are plausible but somewhat speculative, and it could do more to interrogate counterarguments, rebound effects, and cultural/economic constraints. Overall, reasonable and well‑structured support for the thesis, but several important claims depend on uncertain or thin evidence.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Major empirical claims in the post are well supported. Reliable sources show tens of billions of land animals (~83 billion land animals slaughtered in 2022) and many tens-to-hundreds of billions of fish (estimates ~78–171 billion farmed finfish in 2019; wild-capture fish in the trillions) — consistent with the post’s claim that ‘billions’ of land and sea animals suffer each year. Evidence also supports that the vast majority of terrestrial livestock in some countries (e.g. ~99% in the U.S. by SI/OWID definitions) are kept in intensive systems, and there is documented progress from policy, corporate, research and alternative-protein investment that plausibly justifies cautious optimism. Weaknesses/uncertainties: (a) fish and wild-capture numbers are method-sensitive and reported as biomass in many official sources so converting to individual animals has large uncertainty ranges; (b) “inhumane” or “extreme confinement” is partly normative (but many practices — battery cages, gestation crates, crowded broiler barns — are well documented); (c) future trajectories and long-run effectiveness of interventions remain uncertain. Overall: most major factual claims can be verified, but some numerical details (especially aquatic counts and subjective welfare labels) have substantial uncertainty.
sources: Our World in Data — 'More than 80 billion land animals are slaughtered for meat every year' (May 31, 2024)
FAO — The State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture (SOFIA) 2024 (report; global aquatic animal production, 2022 figures)

Mood, Brooke et al., 'Estimating global numbers of farmed fishes killed for food annually from 1990 to 2019' (Animal Welfare, 2023; PubMed/PMC) — estimate 78–171 billion farmed finfish (mean ~124B) in 2019
Rethink Priorities — 'Forecasting Farmed Animal Numbers in 2033' (2023) — projections including shrimps/insects (midpoint ~6 trillion slaughtered by 2033 in some scenarios)
Sentience Institute / Our World in Data analysis — estimates that ~99% of US farmed animals live on factory farms (analysis based on USDA/CAFO definitions)
Good Food Institute — State of the Industry / investment data on alternative proteins (investment totals and trends 2020–2024)

Mercy For Animals press release & Open Philanthropy grant records — large philanthropic funding for corporate campaigns and farm-animal welfare (e.g., Mercy For Animals $12.47M grant from Open Phil, 2023)
The Humane Society of the United States — reporting on McDonald’s achievement of 100% U.S. cage-free eggs (2023/2024) — example of corporate policy change
Compassion in World Farming — data and synthesis on numbers of land animals slaughtered and welfare impacts (summary of global land-animal counts, 2022 figures)
FishCount (and related peer-reviewed syntheses) — estimates of 1.1–2.2 trillion wild-caught fish annually (2000–2019 average) and discussion of fish welfare
